name: Wolf Hollow - North American Wolf Foundation
description: Educational sanctuary dedicated to wolf conservation and education, featuring guided tours and educational programs about North American wolves.

name: Halibut Point State Park
description: Scenic coastal park featuring rocky shores, tide pools, and panoramic ocean views from former granite quarry site.

name: The Mary Baker Eddy Library
description: Research library and museum dedicated to the life and work of Mary Baker Eddy, founder of Christian Science, featuring the famous Mapparium globe.

name: Adams National Historical Park
description: Historic homes and landscapes associated with four generations of the Adams family, including presidents John Adams and John Quincy Adams.

name: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site
description: The home, office, and archives of America's foremost landscape architect, featuring exhibits on his design philosophy and major works.

name: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
description: Birthplace and boyhood home of President John F. Kennedy, preserved as it was during his early years.

name: Lowell National Historical Park
description: Preserved mill complex showcasing America's Industrial Revolution, with working textile demonstrations and canal boat tours.

name: Lowell National Historical Park Visitor Center
description: Gateway to Lowell's industrial heritage with exhibits, films, and tour information for the historic mill district.

name: Boott Cotton Mills Museum
description: Interactive museum in a restored 1835 textile mill featuring working power looms and exhibits on industrial working conditions.

name: The New England Quilt Museum
description: Dedicated to preserving and celebrating the art and history of quilting with rotating exhibitions of traditional and contemporary works.

name: National Streetcar Museum at Lowell
description: Historic trolley cars and streetcar memorabilia showcasing New England's transportation heritage.

name: Patrick J Mogan Cultural Center
description: Cultural center celebrating Lowell's immigrant heritage through exhibits, performances, and community programs.

name: Mill Girls and Immigrants Exhibit (Lowell NHP)
description: Exhibit chronicling the experiences of young women who worked in Lowell's textile mills and the immigrant communities that followed.

name: Minute Man National Historical Park
description: Site of the opening battle of the American Revolution, preserving the historic landscape along the Battle Road.

name: North Bridge Visitor Center
description: Visitor center at the site of the shot heard round the world, offering exhibits and films about April 19, 1775.

name: Major John Buttrick House
description: Historic colonial home of the militia leader who commanded the colonial forces at Concord's North Bridge during the Revolutionary War.

name: Hartwell Tavern
description: Restored 18th-century tavern where travelers once stopped for food, drink, and overnight lodging along the old Boston Post Road.

name: The Wayside Home of Authors
description: Historic home where Nathaniel Hawthorne, Louisa May Alcott, and Margaret Sidney lived and wrote their famous works.

name: New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park
description: Preserves the history of the world's premier whaling port, featuring the Whaling Museum and historic waterfront district.

name: Faneuil Hall Visitor Center
description: Information center for Boston's Freedom Trail and Revolutionary War sites, located in the historic Cradle of Liberty.

name: Old South Meeting House
description: Site of the Boston Tea Party meeting in 1773, this historic church was the largest building in colonial Boston.

name: Old State House
description: Boston's oldest public building and the site of the Boston Massacre, now a museum of Revolutionary history.

name: The Paul Revere House
description: Downtown Boston's oldest building and home of patriot Paul Revere at the time of his famous midnight ride.

name: Old North Church
description: Boston's oldest standing church building, famous for the two lanterns that signaled Paul Revere's midnight ride.

name: Bunker Hill Monument
description: 221-foot granite obelisk commemorating the first major battle of the American Revolution, with 294 steps to the top.

name: Charlestown Navy Yard
description: Historic naval shipyard where USS Constitution and other famous ships were built and maintained from 1801 to 1974.

name: USS Constitution
description: Old Ironsides, the world's oldest commissioned naval vessel still afloat, launched in 1797 and still sailing today.

name: USS Constitution Museum
description: Interactive museum telling the story of Old Ironsides and the sailors who served aboard America's Ship of State.

name: USS Cassin Young
description: Built in 1943 in San Pedro, California, USS Cassin Young is one of 175 Fletcher-class destroyers built during World War II. She engaged in seven Pacific battles during World War II, survived two Kamikaze hits, and served another full decade beyond her expected lifetime.

name: Dorchester Heights
description: Site where George Washington placed cannons to force British evacuation of Boston in 1776, featuring monument and harbor views.

name: Boston Athenaeum
description: One of America's oldest independent libraries, famous for its rare book collection and the notorious book bound in human skin. Look for the skin book.

name: Brook Farm Historic Site
description: Site of the famous 1840s utopian community where transcendentalists like Nathaniel Hawthorne lived and worked.

name: Ether Dome
description: Historic surgical amphitheater at Massachusetts General Hospital where the first public demonstration of anesthesia took place in 1846.

name: James P. Kelleher Rose Garden
description: Beautiful rose garden in the Back Bay Fens featuring hundreds of rose varieties blooming from June through October.

name: Franklin Park - Overlook Ruins
description: The often-overlooked ruins of one of the first buildings designed by famous landscape architect Frederick Olmsted.

name: Pawtucket Dam
description: Historic dam that powered Lowell's textile mills during the Industrial Revolution, still functioning today for flood control.

name: Museum of Science
description: Interactive science museum featuring hands-on exhibits, an IMAX theater, and the Van de Graaff generator lightning show.

name: Winthrop Lane
description: Check for bricks - These whimsical works of art tell the story of the city's past and present.

name: King's Chapel
description: Historic Unitarian Universalist church built on Anglican foundations, featuring beautiful Georgian architecture. Visit the crypt.

name: Creek Square
description: This historic patch of real estate offers a glimpse of colonial Boston

name: Jack Kerouac's Grave
description: Final resting place of Beat Generation author Jack Kerouac in Edson Cemetery, where fans leave offerings of beer and cigarettes.

name: The Harvard Museum of Natural History
description: Famous for the Glass Flowers collection, meteorites, minerals, and specimens showcasing the natural world.

name: Modica Way
description: An alley way dedicated to graffiti and street art is a constantly changing street gallery.

name: Massachusetts Institute of Technology
description: World-renowned institute of technology featuring innovative architecture and the famous infinite corridor.

name: The Museum Of Bad Art
description: The world's only museum dedicated to the collection, preservation, exhibition and celebration of bad art in all its forms.

name: Somerville Theatre
description: Historic independent movie theater and music venue featuring first-run films and live performances since 1914.

name: Sky Bar
description: Rooftop bar and restaurant offering panoramic views and craft cocktails in a relaxed atmosphere.

name: Assabet River National Wildlife Refuge
description: In the middle of a New England forest sit the crumbling ruins of World War II-era ammunition storage bunkers.

name: Ford's Folly
description: This dam in the woods, built by Henry Ford with only manpower and oxen, holds no water and serves no purpose.

name: The Redstone Schoolhouse
description: Historic one-room schoolhouse that inspired the nursery rhyme Mary Had a Little Lamb, now a museum.

name: Newton City Hall
description: Battle dioramas in the Veterans Wing - These impressively detailed battle scenes depict the violence and tragedy of war in miniature.

name: Echo Bridge
description: A historic bridge with a lovely acoustic anomaly.

name: Quincy Quarries Reservation
description: From economic backbone of a community to deadly diving hole, these former stone quarries are now a park for rock climbers and graffiti artists.

name: Brattle Book Shop
description: One of America's oldest antiquarian bookshops, featuring three floors of rare books and an outdoor sale lot.

name: Metropolitan Waterworks Museum
description: Beautiful steampunk ghosts of early Massachusetts.

name: American Heritage Museum
description: Military history museum featuring tanks, aircraft, and artifacts from American conflicts spanning three centuries.

name: Arthur & Elizabeth Schlesinger Library
description: Research library at Harvard focusing on women's history, featuring a huge culinary collection and manuscripts.

name: Harvard Film Archive
description: Academic film archive and cinema showing rare, experimental, and international films not found elsewhere.

name: Powderhouse Park
description: Small park surrounding the historic Old Powder House, a Revolutionary War era gunpowder storage facility.

name: Charles River Museum of Industry & Innovation
description: A steampunk wonderland that preserves America's history of industrial innovation.

name: Club Passim
description: Legendary folk music club where Joan Baez, Bob Dylan, and countless others launched their careers in an intimate setting.

name: Boston Cyberarts Gallery
description: Contemporary gallery showcasing digital and new media art, featuring interactive installations and virtual reality experiences.

name: Reflecting Pool at the Christian Science Plaza
description: Massive 670-foot reflecting pool creating a serene urban oasis in the heart of Boston's Back Bay.

name: Washington Tower
description: Stone observation tower built
